questions.text: One of the following is more prominent in female cranium
questions.solution:
The glabella, supraorbital ridges, zygomatic arch and mastoid process are more prominent in males than females; whereas the frontal and parietal eminences are more prominent in females.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 59.

choices.text: Weight and height of the erupting teeth

questions.text: Stack's method is used to estimate the age by
questions.solution:
Stack’s method is used to Estimate of the age of infants from the weight and height of the erupting teeth of child. It is used on both deciduous and permanent during their erupting phase. Mile’s method is used to estimate the age by studying only the root transparency of a tooth after the age of 30 years. Lamendil’s method is used to estimate the age from using only 2 criteria namely, Gingival Recession and Root Transparency and Boyde’s method is used to estimate the age by incremental lines.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page

questions.text: 'coma vigil' is classically seen in?
questions.solution:
Neuropsychiatric manifestation occur in 2-40% of patients of enteric fever and include meningitis, Guillain-Barre syndrome, neuritis, and neuropsychiatric symptoms (described as "muttering delirium" or "coma vigil"), with picking at bedclothes or imaginary objects.

Reference : Harrison's principle of internal medicine 21st edition, page no-1294.

questions.text: Dangerous injury is
questions.solution:
Dangerous injuries are those which cause imminent danger to life, either by involvement of important organs or structures or extensive area of the body. Fracture of tibia and loss of vision are grievous hurt but not a dangerous injury, whereas minimal amount of EDH to be fatal is 100ml; so more than 100ml is dangerous injury.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 274

questions.text: Not a feature of histopathological changes of electric burn is
questions.solution:
In an electrical burn, histologically there will be elongation of cells, streaming of nuclei and vacuolisation.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 309

questions.text: 'Baby - farmer' refers to
questions.solution:
Children starved by their parents are known as “Baby-farmer”.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 314

choices.text: Line on hip bone for sex determination
Line on femur for sex determination
Line on hip bone for race determination
Line in femur bone for race determination

questions.text: Chilotic line is?
questions.solution:
Chilotic line is a Chilotic line is an anthropometric line extending from the posterior aspect of theiliopectineal eminence to the closest point on the ant. auricular margin (the pelvic segment) and then to the iliac crest (the sacral portion);

Males → Sacral part is prominent

Females → Pelvic part is prominent Helps to differentiate sex of a person

Reference: TB of FMT. 1st Edition, Anil Aggrawal, Page No. 69

questions.text: Most common organ involved in blunt abdominal injury is
questions.solution:
The most common organ involved in blunt abdominal injury is spleen, the most common penetrating abdominal injury organ is liver and the most common seat belt injury in abdomen is mesentery.

Reference: SRB edition 6, Chapter Trauma.

questions.text: The minimum tension required to constrict trachea in case of hanging is
questions.solution:
A tension of 2 Kg is sufficient to constrict jugular veins, 4-5 Kg is required to constrict carotid artery, 15 Kg to block the trachea and 30 Kg to constrict vertebral artery.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 316

questions.text: A suppositious child is
questions.solution:
Suppositious child means a fictitious child. A woman may pretend pregnancy and delivery and later produce a living child as her own, or she may substitute a male child for female child born of her, or for an abortion.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 372

questions.text: In living persons sperms are motile in vagina upto
questions.solution:
In living persons, motile sperms are usually seen upto 6 hours and rarely 12 hours after ejaculation into the vagina.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr.K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 407

questions.text: A person is not held liable criminally in case of
questions.solution:
Automatism is the performance of actions without conscious thought or intention, hence not held criminally responsible. In kleptomania, the person knows that what he is doing and he knows that what he is doing is wrong. Hypnosis is an act with consent.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 462

questions.text: In acute arsenic poisoning, maximum amount is seen in
questions.solution:
Arsenic is normally present in almost all tissues. In the early stage, arsenic is found in greatest quantity in the liver, followed by kidneys and spleen.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 503

questions.text: Average blood alcohol required for alcohol gaze nystagmus is
questions.solution:
When the jerking movement of the eyeball is in the direction of the gaze and independent of the position of the head, it is known as alcohol gaze nystagmus and appears at blood levels of 40 to 100 mg% (Average 80 mg%).

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 531

questions.text: Not attending summons is punishable under
questions.solution:
Section 174 of IPC - Non-attendance in obedience to an order from public servant.—Whoever, being legally bound to attend in person or by an agent at a certain place and time in obedience to a summons, notice, order or proclamation proceeding from any public servant legally competent, as such public servant, to issue the same, intentionally omits to attend at that place or time, or departs from the place where he is bound to attend before the time at which it is lawful for him to depart, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five hun­dred rupees, or with both, or, if the summons, notice, order or proclamation is to attend in person or by agent in a Court of Justice, with simple imprison­ment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.

Reference: Indian Penal Code

questions.text: Absent or fragmented medulla is seen in all EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Human hair, except for the hair of native Mongolians, has either no medulla or a fragmented medulla. Mongoloids hair usually has continuous medulla.

Reference: Criminal investigation, 3rd Edition, Ronald F. Becker, Page No. 301

questions.text: The earliest ossification centre to appear in a normal pregnancy is of
questions.solution:
The ossification centre for shaft of clavicle appears at 4-5 weeks, for mandible at 6 weeks, for shaft of femur at 8 weeks and capitate ossifies at 2 months.

Reference: TB of FMT. 1st Edition, Anil Aggrawal, Page No. 82

questions.text:
Alkaline pyrogallol test helps to differentiate between
i) Pneumothorax and putrefactive necrosis
ii) Pneumothorax and post mortem lividity
iii) Post mortem lividity and putrefactive necrosis
iv) Air embolism and putrefactive necrosis
questions.solution:
Alkaline Pyrogallol test: This test helps to differentiate air embolism, pneumothorax from putrefactive gases produced by bacteria like clostridium welchii post mortem. Here thus, options (i) and (iv) are right. Post mortem lividity or vibices or post mortem staining are colour phenomenon that occurs due to capillary dilatation and breakdown of haemoglobin deposited in tissues and has nothing to do with air or gas, hence is not considered here.

4 mL of alkaline pyrogallol is taken in a 10mL syringe and air is aspirated from right side of the heart. The needle is removed and replaced by a stopper. If air (Oxygen) is present, the mixture turns brown on shaking. In a second syringe, some air is introduced by the atmosphere and the test is repeated as a control. In case of putrefactive gases, the colour doesn’t change.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 104

questions.text: Warning notice is issued to a registered medical practitioner for
questions.solution:
Warning notice: MCI can issue Warning Notice containing certain practices which are regarded as falling within the meaning of the term “Professional Misconduct”, which is issued to all the doctors at the time of registration. It is not a disciplinary action.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 26

questions.text: Large irregular entrance wound may be seen in
questions.solution:
Where a thin layer of skin overlies bone, as in the head, the gases expand between the skin and the outer table of the skull, lifting up and ballooning out the skin. If the stretching exceeds the elasticity of the skin, it will tear. These tears radiate from the entrance, producing a stellate or cruciform appearing wound of entrance.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 209

questions.text: Cause of death in Commotio cordis is
questions.solution:
Commotio cordis typically involves young (8-18 years; average age is 15), predominantly male, athletes in whom a sudden, blunt, non-penetrating and innocuous-appearing trauma to the anterior chest results in cardiac arrest and sudden death from ventricular fibrillation.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 252

questions.text: The causative electrode of electric injury can be identified by
questions.solution:
Acro-reaction test is a micro-chemical test for metals at the site of entry. Helps to identify the wound of entry. Small balls of molten metal, derived from the electrode, may be carried deep into the tissues, known as current Pearls). Melted CaPO4, seen as round density foci on X-ray, known as bone pearls or wax drippings

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 375

questions.text: All the following give rise to dimness of cornea before death EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Glistening of cornea remains even after death in case of CO and Cyanide poisoning. Dimness of cornea before death occurs in Cholera, Uraemia, Narcotic poisoning and wasting disease.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 145

choices.text: Floating only after 24 hours as normal

questions.text: Deep inspiration prior to death in a drowning case in summer may lead to
questions.solution:
The floatation of the body is due to putrefactive gases and is not at all related to the inspired air. In India body floats in about 12-18 hours in summer, and 18-36 hours in winter.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 351

questions.text: The test in which weight of lungs is compared with body weight is
questions.solution:
As per Plocquet’s Test, the ratio between the weight of the lung and body is:1:70 before respiration and 1:35 after respiration. As per Fodere’s/Static Test: Before respiration the weight of the lungs is about 35g, and after respiration it will be about 70g. According to Wredin’s Test, there is replacement of gelatinous tissue in the middle ear by air after respiration.

Raygat’s test is hydrostatic test.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 411

questions.text: The most preferred method of DNA analysis currently used in crime laboratories is
questions.solution:
For forensic purposes STR typing is the recommended method, which must involve the study of at least 13 core loci.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 433

choices.text: Watching the opposite sex person undressing
Rubbing the genitals to opposite sex person

questions.text: 'Eonism' refers to
questions.solution:
Transvestism is known as eonism. It is usually found in males who obtain sexual pleasure by wearing female dress.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 405

questions.text: Reversal of hot/cold temperature perception is seen in
questions.solution:
Ciguatera fish poisoning: Ciguatoxin found in certain algae and protozoa are eten by herbivorous fish, which in turn are eaten by large fish which become poisonous. Ciguatoxin alters the Na+ permeability giving rise to reversal of hot/cold temperature perception – Hot substances feel cold and cold substances feel hot.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 593

questions.text: 'Xanthopsia' is seen in poisoning by
questions.solution:
Xanthopsia is a visual disturbance characterized by excessive perception of yellow colours (literally “yellow vision”). It may be associated with the use of various drugs including digoxin (especially if levels are toxic), thiazides (especially chlorothiazide), sulphonamides, and barbiturates.

Reference: A dictionary of neurological signs, 4th Edition, A.J. Larner, Page No. 343

questions.text: Culpable homicide not amounting to murder is defined under IPC section
questions.solution:
This section not only defines murder, but also defines when culpable homicide is not murder.

299- Culpable homicide, 304- Punishment for culpable homicide not amounting to murder, and 308- Punishment for attempt to commit culpable homicide

Reference: Section 300 of IPC:

questions.text: The word subpoena is synonymous with :
questions.solution:
Subpoena (Sub = Under), Poena = Penalty – It is a legal document, compelling the attendance of a person in a court of law, under penaltyi. Subpoena is also known as summons

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 8

questions.text: Mechanical obstruction of the flow of air from the environment into the mouth and/or nostril is ?
questions.solution:
Smothering is the mechanical obstruction of the flow of air from the environment into the mouth and/or nostrils, for instance, by covering the mouth and nose with a hand, pillow, or a plastic bag.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 337

choices.text: Is not allowed to testify in a court of law
Can testify by signs in an open court.
By producing a previously written statement

questions.text: A dumb witness:
questions.solution:
Dumb witnesses:

A witness who is unable to speak may give his evidence in any other manner in which he can make it intelligible, as by writing or by signs; but such writing must be written and the signs made in open Court.

Evidence so given shall be deemed to be oral evidence.

Reference: TB of FMT. 1st Edition, Anil Aggrawal, Page No. 20

questions.text: All of the following are related to medical negligence except :
questions.solution:
Section 304A I.P.C - Whoever causes the death of any person by doing any rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

Section 341 I.P.C. - Punishment for wrongful restraint

Section 312 I.P.C. - Causing miscarriage

Section 37 I.P.C. - Co-operation by doing one of several acts constituting an offence.

Reference: Indian Penal Code

questions.text: Exposure and abandonment of child under twelve years by his parents may lead to their prosecution under section
questions.solution:
Section 317 in The Indian Penal Code - Exposure and abandonment of child under twelve years, by parent or person having care of it.

Whoever being the father or mother of a child under the age of twelve years, or having the care of such child, shall expose or leave such child in any place with the intention of wholly abandoning such child, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.

Reference: Indian Penal Code

questions.text: Under which section of the Indian law is incest punishable?
questions.solution:
Incest per se is not punishable in India; unless it amounts to rape.

Reference: Indian Penal Code

questions.text: Sin of Gommorrah is another name for
questions.solution:
Buccal coitus is also known as coitus per os or sin of Gommorrah. The male organ is introduced into Mouth.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 401

questions.text: Boiled lobster appearance is seen in?
questions.solution:
Extensive desquamating skin lesion (“boiled lobster” appearance) is seen in boric acid poisoning.

Reference: TB of FMT. 1st Edition, Anil Aggrawal, Page No. 582

questions.text: A 18-year-old young female comes to a male gynaecologist for pelvic examination, in presence of a female nurse. The type of consent consent for examination is :
questions.solution:
Common medical procedures (OPD) and examinations do not necessitate written consent unless any invasive procedure is being done as it is regarded that when a patient comes to the doctor, they are implying their will to be examined (restricted to general physical examination) and further systemic and local examination requires only verbal consent. All invasive procedures such as blood transfusions, surgeries, HIV testing etc may require written consent prior to action.

Implied consent is inferred from signs, actions, or facts, or by inaction or silence. Implied consent differs from express consent, which is communicated by the spoken or written word. For routine pelvic examination, verbal consent is to be taken and in case of male RMO, it has to be performed in the presence of a female nurse or female attendant.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 48,49

questions.text: Quantum of punishment for rape is imprisonment for
questions.solution:
Amendment of section 376

In section 376 of the Penal Code,—

in sub-section (1), for the words 'shall not be less than seven years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to tine', the words 'shall not be less than ten years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine' shall be substituted;

Reference: The Criminal law (Amendment) ordinance, 2018

questions.text: Juvenile justice board shall always consist of
questions.solution:
The Juvenile Justice Board consists of three persons comprising of:

  1. One Metropolitan Magistrate or a Judicial Magistrate of the first class (Usually a female).
  2. Two social workers, of whom at least one shall be a woman.

Reference: Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015

questions.text: En mass removal at autopsy is called
questions.solution:
Lettulle’s technique: Cervical, thoracic, abdominal and pelvis organs are removed En masse.

Virchow's technique: Individual organs are removed one by one.

Ghon’s technique: Block dissection-Cervical, thoracic, abdominal organs and urogenital systems are removed as Organ blocks.

Rokitansky’s technique: In situ dissection.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 104, 105

questions.text: In how many hours does a dead body float in India in summer?
questions.solution:
Floatation of body in India occurs in about 12-18 hours in summer and 18-36 hours in winter.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 351

questions.text: Which of the following is not a principle of medical ethics
questions.solution:
The 4 basic principles of medical ethics are

  1. Respect for autonomy: Respect the decisions made by other people concerning their own lives.
  2. Beneficence: Action done for the benefit of others.
  3. Non-maleficence: 'Do no harm'.
  4. Justice: Treat all people equally, fairly, and impartially.

Reference: Evidence-Based Medical Ethics: Cases for Practice-Based Learning, 1st edition, John E. Snyder, Candace C. Gauthier, Page No. 11

questions.text: Double base smokeless gun powder contains
questions.solution:
Smokeless powder may be - Single based which contain only Nitrocellulose or double based which contain Nitrocellulose and Nitroglycerin or triple based which contain Nitrocellulose, Nitroglycerine and Nitroguanidine.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 203

choices.text: At any time before full term

questions.text: Legally, abortion means - termination of pregnancy
questions.solution:
Legally, Abortion (miscarriage) means the premature expulsion of products of conception from mother’s womb, either spontaneous or induced at any time before full term.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 374

questions.text: Rigor mortis reaches peak, when muscle ATP is reduced by
questions.solution:
When the ATP is reduced to 85% of the normal, the overlapping portions of myosin and action filaments combine as rigid links of actomyosin, which is viscous and inextensible and causes hardness and rigidity of muscle rigor. The rigidity of the muscle is t its maximum, when the level of the ATP is reduced to 15%.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 152

questions.text: Most difficult criteria in Gustafson's method to recognize and assess is
questions.solution:
Out of all criteria in Gustafson’s method of age estimation of a person by the secondary changes in the teeth, Root Resorption is the most difficult criteria to recognize and assess is and is least reliable.

Reference: The Textbook of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 1st edition, Dr. Anil Aggrawal, Page No. 88

questions.text: Antidote for Cocaine is
questions.solution:
In case of cocaine overdose, amyl nitrite is the antidote which is given by inhalation.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 34th edition, Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, Page No. 560

questions.text: The minimum age at which an individual is responsible for his criminal act is
questions.solution:
Act of a child under seven years of age.—Nothing is an offence which is done by a child under seven years of age.

Reference: Section 82 in The Indian Penal Code
